title: 108_s2919
content: The text introduces a new subpart in the Internal Revenue Code providing a nonrefundable credit for holders of Indian Tribal Prison Facility Bonds. The new subpart in the Internal Revenue Code offers a nonrefundable credit for taxpayers holding Indian tribal prison facility bonds. Taxpayers can claim a credit against their tax for the year based on the credit rate and face amount of the bond held on the credit allowance date. The new subpart in the Internal Revenue Code provides a nonrefundable credit for taxpayers with Indian tribal prison facility bonds. The credit rate is determined monthly by the Secretary to allow for bond issuance without discount or interest cost. The credit amount for a taxable year is limited by the taxpayer's regular tax liability and other allowable credits. Gross income includes the credit amount. The new subpart in the Internal Revenue Code offers a nonrefundable credit for taxpayers with Indian tribal prison facility bonds. Gross income includes the credit amount, treated as interest income. Indian tribal prison facility bonds are defined as bonds issued for specific purposes by the Indian tribe within the facility's jurisdiction. The new subpart in the Internal Revenue Code provides a nonrefundable credit for taxpayers with Indian tribal prison facility bonds. These bonds must be issued by the Indian tribe for specific purposes, have a term not exceeding 10 years, and limit issuance costs to 2 percent of sale proceeds. A qualified Indian tribal prison facility is a correctional or detention facility on tribal land with mostly tribal member inmates. The Internal Revenue Code introduces a nonrefundable credit for taxpayers holding Indian tribal prison facility bonds. The bonds must be issued by the tribe for specific purposes, with a term not exceeding 10 years and issuance costs limited to 2 percent of sale proceeds. The Indian tribal prison facility bond limitation is set at $200,000,000 for 2005, 2006, and 2007, with zero allocation thereafter. The Secretary will allocate the bond limitation among tribes submitting a plan detailing the use of investment proceeds. The Secretary will allocate the Indian tribal prison facility bond limitation among tribes based on criteria including prison overcrowding, facility conditions, and health and safety considerations for inmates and employees. The Indian tribal prison facility bond limitation will be allocated based on criteria such as prison overcrowding, facility conditions, health and safety considerations for inmates and employees, type of offenders incarcerated, and other financial resources available to the tribe. Any unused limitation amount can be carried over to future years until used. The text chunk discusses the allowance of tax credits to shareholders of regulated investment companies holding Indian tribal prison facility bonds, along with reporting requirements for Indian tribes with bond allocations. Additionally, there are conforming amendments related to reporting of credits on these bonds. The text chunk discusses the inclusion of certain amounts in gross income as interest for tax credit purposes, reporting requirements for corporations, and regulatory authority for implementing necessary regulations. The text chunk introduces a special rule for holders of Indian Tribal Prison Facility Bonds regarding estimated tax payments for individuals and corporations. The text introduces a special rule for holders of Indian Tribal Prison Facility Bonds regarding estimated tax payments for individuals and corporations. The amendment allows the credit allowed by section 54 to be treated as a payment of estimated tax. Additionally, clerical amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment introduces a nonrefundable credit for holders of Indian Tribal Prison Facility Bonds. Section 6401(b)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include this new credit. The effective date for these amendments is obligations issued after December 31, 2004.
